forumNotes.author: Yoav
forumNotes.content:
I'm looking for an application that I thought would be pretty easy to find but apparently nobody has thought of this idea.   

I'm a computer technician, and as one, I carry around discs. Applications, operating systems and rescue discs, as well as drivers and backups.   
Last month I bought brand new portable external hard drive with 320GB of space and I couldn't be happier, all those CDs/DVDs I use to carry around with me, I can now just make into ISOs and use DAEMON Tools or Power ISO to mount them as a virtual drive.  

The problem is, I can't do this with BOOTABLE discs.   
So I still need to carry around all my rescue discs and operating system install discs.  

I WISH there was a program that I can install on my external drive, along with a folder called ISO'S that whenever I connect my external hard drive to a new computer, I choose to boot from it and it loads a virtual drive and gives me a list of the ISOs files available on the folder.  

I choose the ISO, and the program boots from it.   

**A PRE-OS Virtual Drive Manager!**   

That would save me so much time and make my job a lot easier, plus I can stop carrying discs around and just use my hard drive for everything!  

Has anybody seen anything like that around? Anything at all?   

Please let me know!

forumNotes.author: Brito
forumNotes.content:
This sounds very interesting but haven't heard of such elaborate tool yet. If you interested in beginning such project it might certainly grow popular. -------- To load ISO's I'd recommend Imdisk (the developer is a member here) - it's open source and very flexible. For the ISO boot portion it gets a bit more complicated since each ISO has it's boot characteristics. Grub4Dos could be used to handle multiboot (the developer is also a member here) without worries but it would require some tweaking on the settings. ---------------------------- Since you're proposing a front end to all these things, it would be fun to see a sort of wizard asking the user some basic questions about the ISO image that he would like to add and this way arrange all the necessary settings to add the image onto the external harddrive (ready to boot if desired).
Damian666 is usually available for creating these sort of tools, if you need help coding the frontend then he might be the right person. :smile:

forumNotes.author: mr_
forumNotes.content:
Yes, I am always dreaming about a *pre-boot operating system* , perhaps including to kick out legacy BIOS and to completely rewritten as Open Source.  

But what you ask for doesn't exist. Well, there are workarrounds. A workarround is never a replacement.  

Booting CD's on computers with function able BIOS to boot CD is a 100 % portable solution, I've seen only rare cases where this isn't working.  

Buggy BIOS and USB booting problems are common. There are workarrounds but not 100 % replacement.  

Like mentioned grub4dos can be used to emulate an iso (CD or DVD) at boot time to an boot it. But it's "only" (in quotes, because this is already great) 100 % portable as long only real mode operating systems access the device thought BIOS calls. As soon a protected/long mode operating system will try to direct access the device it will fail as it does not exists in reality and there is no driver. (However, with great effort it would be possible to develop such a feature.)  

There are operating system specific workarrounds available (xp setup from usb, PEtoUSB, transfering linux live cd's to usb, USBoot...).  

Another option is to use USB pendrives with a 'good' firmeware, a few of them are capable of emulating a CD-ROM and it will look 'real' to the operating system, so it's bootable. But a lot limitations, currently only pendrives, no USB HDD, only 1 CD (maybe workarround multi boot cd) pendrive, USB-CDROM booting problems have been inherited (buggy/old BIOS's). This area is also very experimental.  

It all involves a lot learning and trouble, like said there is no 100 % replacement for legacy CD-ROM yet, but this doesn't mean it's not worth to invest into USB booting.

>

Yes, grub4dos can do exactly that.  

The problem, as it was already mentioned, is that once the OS "kicks in" there may be NOT an appropriate driver to replace the pre-OS Virtual Drive driver.  

So:  
ALL DOS based images (Real Mode) do work  
ALL Linux based images can work, for some tweaking is needed on the Linux side  
SOME NT based images work (i.e. those based on RAMDISK booting)  
At the moment it has not been found an alternate driver (or a way to use it) to boot a NT based system without using the Server 2003 SP1 or R2( NOT "gold" NOT SP2) ramdisk.sys and setupldr.bin or the equivalent Commercial alternative Diskleesangel.
